name: Critical Path and Desktop Development Ecosystem
description: This feature encompasses all critical functionality paths for various Linux spins, desktop environments, and their associated software development tools. It provides a comprehensive set of packages and configurations to guarantee the critical functionality of base systems, desktop environments (GNOME, KDE, LXDE, Xfce, and Server editions), and standard setups. Additionally, it supports the full development ecosystem for graphical applications and frameworks associated with these environments, including GNOME, KDE (Frameworks 5 and 6), and Xfce. This feature ensures a robust platform for both end-user environments and advanced application development.

name: System Utilities and Tools Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and utilities designed for system management, performance optimization, hardware support, debugging, network management, development, security, scientific computations, and graphical or headless system administration. This parent feature consolidates software packages for system administrators, developers, scientists, and engineers, enabling effective control, analysis, and customization for desktop, server, and enterprise environments. Whether graphical or command-line-based, these tools provide essential functionality for system monitoring, performance tuning, hardware interaction, networking, and more.

name: Development and Platform Support
description: This parent feature encompasses a comprehensive suite of tools, libraries, frameworks, and platforms that enable development, deployment, and execution of applications across a variety of languages, environments, and use cases. It includes support for programming languages, scripting, web application frameworks, runtime environments, text rendering, and interoperability with external systems, making it essential for developers and administrators working on diverse projects in Linux environments.

name: System and Network Services
description: A comprehensive collection of features for configuring, managing, and hosting network-based services, identity management, storage solutions, and application services. This parent feature encapsulates client and server-side functionalities, high-availability solutions, cloud infrastructure capabilities, and tools for enabling a wide range of system and network use cases, such as hosting websites, running mail and FTP servers, managing user identities, printing solutions, and providing load balancing for applications and services. It also supports legacy and modern protocols, resilient storage, and advanced network configurations for both local and distributed environments.

name: Lightweight Desktop Environment Features
description: A comprehensive set of features and applications for lightweight desktop environments, including LXDE, LXQt, Xfce, and Deepin. These features provide essential functionality, multimedia support, office productivity tools, and user interface enhancements, designed for systems with low hardware specifications or users who prefer lightweight, efficient desktop solutions. The collection also includes critical path functionality, translations, multimedia frameworks, and additional plugins to extend the usability and performance of these desktop environments.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Cloud and Virtualization Management Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and utilities designed for managing cloud environments, virtualization platforms, containers, and related technologies. This feature encapsulates functionalities across bootloader tools for cloud images, server and system image management in cloud infrastructures, virtualization environments, remote desktop management, and container orchestration. Additionally, it includes platform-specific virtualization utilities, guest agents for hypervisors, and remote management interfaces to support both headless and graphical virtualization needs, providing seamless integration and robust management capabilities for modern Linux-based infrastructure.

name: Linux System Feature Model
description: This parent feature provides a comprehensive modeling of all functional and structural components necessary for various Linux product variants, their dependencies, conflicts, and critical path functionalities. It encapsulates support for different installation types, including the minimal core features, package conflicts for streamlined installations, critical paths for key operations, ostree support, and specialized package groups for design, development, and variant-specific installations.

name: Desktop Environments and Graphical User Interfaces
description: This feature encompasses a wide variety of graphical user interface environments, desktop environments, window managers, and supporting technologies for Linux systems. It provides users with options for traditional, modern, and highly configurable UX environments, catering to diverse needs ranging from minimalistic setups to complete desktop environments with accessibility and application support. The feature includes desktop systems such as GNOME, Budgie, Cinnamon, MATE, and lighter environments like i3, XMonad, and Sway. It also includes legacy X Window System compatibility and development tools, ensuring support for older and modern graphical setups, as well as tools and applications enhancing user experience, accessibility, gaming, and entertainment.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop

name: Database Management Systems (DBMS)
description: A comprehensive category encompassing various software solutions and tools used for managing and interacting with relational and non-relational databases. This feature includes database server and client implementations, as well as components for creating, querying, and maintaining databases. It covers popular database systems, enterprise-level solutions, and open source alternatives, catering to a wide range of database management needs, from development to production environments.

name: Linux Development and Productivity Ecosystem
description: A comprehensive feature encapsulating tools, libraries, environments, and utilities designed for software development, compatibility, desktop productivity, educational purposes, and more. It includes development frameworks, toolkits, compilers, editors, and compatibility libraries, as well as packages focused on learning, writing, science, and multimedia production. This feature is ideal for users ranging from software developers and technical writers to educators and researchers aiming to build, deploy, and interact with a versatile Linux environment.
